I guess I am missing the point of why it matters what class lever it is. Don't they all work the same way. And I guess I also don't see the difference between resistance and effort, just a matter of perspective.

Would you be willing to do a video on the leverage used in curb bits on horses and how much force some common curb bits apply to the horse's head and where, and how to calculate the force a curb bit would apply to horse's head on the poll, chin, and mouth? Then maybe compare the force from curb bits with a snaffle bit? There is an awful lot of leverage using levers and pulleys in the horse world (draw reins, chambons, gag bits, etc.), and I think we'd all be better riders and owners if we understood it better. I know you like helping good causes, how about helping out horses by showing horse owners how their tack really works?

Hey Destin, I have been a subscriber since I think the chicken video and I wanted to thank you for all your work in posting these videos. Question: I have been looking for a long time at finding a good organization to volunteer abroad but I can't afford to go through most places. I am mostly a hands on building and engineering type of guy and would love to use what skills I do have to help those in need. Whether it is just building housing or disaster relief, whatever really. As I said I want to help but can't afford the sometimes thousands of dollars many organizations charge for travel and whatnot. I just want to help and willing to spend the blood and sweat but I still need to get by while I do so. I know you may not have the answers but I figured I would ask for your thoughts. Anyways, thanks again for all of your work and keep it up. Cheers.

Spanish teacher here.  Let me help you become smarter today and return the favor you've been doing us all.

There are two ways to tell someone your name in Spanish:

Me llamo _____. (literally, I call myself ____)

Mi nombre es ___. (literally, my name is ___)

Don't mix the two!  Me llamo es Dustin  = I call myself is Dustin.  They'll get the idea but you instantly label yourself as a stupid Gringo and increase your odds of getting mugged.

Cool video. Thanks for teaching us Levers.

Let me tell you something about Spanish: "Me llamo __" more accurately translates to "I'm called ___" or idiomatically, "They call me __" (though if you actually wanted to say that, its said differently).

So if you say "Me llamo ES ___," you are saying "They call me IS ___," which doesn't sound right in either language. Leave out the "es" and everything makes perfect grammatical sense.
